[[File:Mani Ratnam at the Museum of the Moving Image.jpg|thumbnail|Mani Ratnam at the [[Museum of the Moving Image (New York City)|Museum of the Moving Image]], [[New York City]], in 2015|alt=Mani Ratnam]] [[Mani Ratnam]] is an Indian filmmaker who works predominantly in [[Tamil cinema]]. He is credited with redefining the "range and depth of Tamil cinema",{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zHF1AAAAIAAJ | title=Indian Cinema | publisher=[[Directorate of Film Festivals]] | location=[[Mumbai]] | year=1991 | page=18}} and is regarded as one of the greatest Indian filmmakers.{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.time.com/2005/02/12/all-time-100-movies/slide/nayakan-1987/ | title=All-Time 100 Movies | work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=14 January 2010 | accessdate=29 April 2016 | last=Corliss | first=Richard | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505050739/http://entertainment.time.com/2005/02/12/all-time-100-movies/slide/nayakan-1987/ | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} As of 2018, he has directed 26 films, and produced over 15 under his production company [[Madras Talkies]]. Mani Ratnam made his directorial debut, without formal training or education in filmmaking, with the [[Kannada cinema|Kannada film]] ''[[Pallavi Anu Pallavi]]'' (1983). The critically acclaimed film, which he also wrote, won him the [[Karnataka State Film Award for Best Screenplay]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3mzyPGSfwKMC |title=Rajinikanth: The Definitive Biography |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |last=Ramachandran |first=Naman |location=London |year=2014 |pages=165–166 |isbn=978-81-8475-796-5 |authorlink=Naman Ramachandran |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170108153955/https://books.google.com/books?id=3mzyPGSfwKMC |archivedate=2017-01-08 |df= }} Following a string of commercial failures, he had his first box-office success with the 1985 Tamil film ''[[Idaya Kovil]]''.{{cite news | date=9 November 2012 | first=S | last=Shiva Kumar | url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/leader-for-all-times/article4079107.ece | title=Leader for all times | work=[[The Hindu]] | accessdate=21 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505051415/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/leader-for-all-times/article4079107.ece | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} The following year, he made the [[romantic drama]] ''[[Mouna Ragam]]'', which narrated the story of a young woman who is forced into an arranged marriage by her family.{{cite book|last=Somaaya |first=Bhawana |title=Fragmented Frames: Reflections of a Critic |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WZQLAQAAMAAJ |year=2008 |location=[[New Delhi]] |publisher=[[Pustak Mahal]] |isbn=978-81-223-1016-0 |page=278 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217115236/https://books.google.com/books?id=WZQLAQAAMAAJ |archivedate=2017-02-17 |df= }} The critical and commercial success of the film established him as a leading filmmaker in Tamil cinema.{{cite news | first=Nandini | last=Ramnath | url=http://www.livemint.com/Opinion/Pgp6FRFUhMoAwCVjpfH2CO/CINEMA-CURRENT-Mani-Ratnam-gestures-hypnotically.html | title=Cinema Current: Mani Ratnam gestures hypnotically | work=[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]] | date=8 February 2013 | accessdate=21 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505052338/http://www.livemint.com/Opinion/Pgp6FRFUhMoAwCVjpfH2CO/CINEMA-CURRENT-Mani-Ratnam-gestures-hypnotically.html | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} His next release ''[[Nayakan]]'', starring [[Kamal Haasan]], was inspired by the life of the [[Mumbai|Bombay]]-based gangster [[Varadarajan Mudaliar]].{{cite news | url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/article288682.ece | title='Nayagan' daughter planned to settle in US | work=[[The New Indian Express]] | date=7 October 2010 | accessdate=30 April 2016 | last=Tejonmayam | first=U | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505052221/http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/article288682.ece | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} The film was submitted by [[List of submissions to the 60th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film|India as its official entry for the 60th Academy Awards]]. Later in 2005, ''Nayakan'' was included in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'''s "[[Time's All-Time 100 Movies|All-Time 100 Movies]]" list.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/A-Brilliant-Tribute-To-The-Wonderful-Kamal-Haasan/quickstirshow/45079862.cms |title=A Brilliant Tribute To The Wonderful Kamal Haasan |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=8 November 2014 |accessdate=30 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6hGpsajO0?url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/A-Brilliant-Tribute-To-The-Wonderful-Kamal-Haasan/quickstirshow/45079862.cms |archivedate=5 May 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} Mani Ratnam followed this with the tragic romance ''[[Geethanjali (1989 film)|Geethanjali]]'' (1989), which marked his [[Telugu cinema]] debut; the tragedy ''[[Anjali (1990 film)|Anjali]]'' (1990),{{efn|The film was India's official entry to the [[63rd Academy Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Indias+Oscar+failures/1/29289.html |title=India's Oscar failures |work=[[India Today]] |date=16 February 2009 |accessdate=30 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505051852/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Indias%2BOscar%2Bfailures/1/29289.html |archivedate= 5 May 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }}}} which narrated the story of an autistic child; and the [[crime drama]] ''[[Thalapathi]]'' (1991), loosely adapted from the Indian epic ''[[Mahabharata]]''.{{cite news | url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/happy-birthday-rajinikanth-how-the-superstar-came-to-be/ | title=Happy Birthday Rajinikanth: How the superstar came to be | work=[[The Indian Express]] | date=12 December 2015 | accessdate=30 April 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505052233/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/happy-birthday-rajinikanth-how-the-superstar-came-to-be/ | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} In 1992, he made the [[romantic thriller]] ''[[Roja]]'' for [[Kavithalayaa Productions]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GTEa93azj9EC&pg=PA165 |title=Bollywood: A Guidebook to Popular Hindi Cinema |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis#Acquired companies & discontinued imprints|Psychology Press]] |last=Ganti |first=Tejaswini |location=[[New York City]] |year=2004 |page=165 |isbn=978-0-415-28854-5 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217110105/https://books.google.com/books?id=GTEa93azj9EC&pg=PA165 |archivedate=2017-02-17 |df= }} The film was [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbed]] into many Indian languages, including Hindi,{{cite web | first1=Anupama | last1=Chandara | url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/started-by-roja-and-jurassic-park-dubbing-for-hollywood-blockbusters-becomes-big-business/1/289543.html | title=Audible success | date=15 November 1995 | accessdate=19 February 2016 | work=India Today | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505051911/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/started-by-roja-and-jurassic-park-dubbing-for-hollywood-blockbusters-becomes-big-business/1/289543.html | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} and its widespread success brought national recognition to Mani Ratnam.{{cite web | first1=Saritha | last1=Rai | url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/mani-ratnams-bombay-views-communalism-through-eyes-of-common-man/1/287685.html | title=Falling in love with the 'Enemy' | date=15 January 1995 | accessdate=21 February 2016 | work=India Today | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505051925/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/mani-ratnams-bombay-views-communalism-through-eyes-of-common-man/1/287685.html | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}}{{cite news | url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/tamil/article298788.ece | title=Will the dubbed ‘Enthiran’ work? | work=The New Indian Express | date=7 September 2010 | accessdate=19 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505052243/http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/tamil/article298788.ece | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}}{{cite web | first1=Saisuresh | last1=Sivaswamy | url=http://movies.rediff.com/review/2010/jun/18/review-raavanan-is-better-than-raavan.htm | title=Vikram's Raavanan is better, as is Prithviraj's Dev | publisher=[[Rediff.com|Rediff]] | date=18 June 2010 | accessdate=19 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505051700/http://movies.rediff.com/review/2010/jun/18/review-raavanan-is-better-than-raavan.htm | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} Three years later, he made ''[[Bombay (film)|Bombay]]'' (1995), which was based on the [[Bombay riots|1992–93 Bombay riots]]. Although controversial for its depiction of religious riots,{{cite web | first=Soutik | last=Biswas | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-28877947 | title=Why India loves to ban films | publisher=[[BBC]] | date=21 August 2014 | accessdate=21 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505052846/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-28877947 | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} the film met with wide critical acclaim and became commercially successful in India.{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/critical-acclaim-and-howls-of-protest-for-mani-ratnam-bombay/1/287840.html|last1=G. Tilak|first1=Sudha|last2=Jung Thapa|first2=Vijay|title=Treading on a dangerous divide|work=India Today|date=15 April 1995|accessdate=30 April 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505051937/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/critical-acclaim-and-howls-of-protest-for-mani-ratnam-bombay/1/287840.html|archivedate=5 May 2016|deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/Bombay-Interesting-facts-about-the-film/photostory/47802356.cms |title=Bombay: Interesting facts about the film |work=The Times of India |accessdate=30 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6hGpyREu6?url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/Bombay-Interesting-facts-about-the-film/photostory/47802356.cms |archivedate=5 May 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} In 1997, Mani Ratnam co-produced and directed the [[political drama]] film ''[[Iruvar]]'',{{efn|The film was the debut venture of [[Madras Talkies]].}} which was loosely based on the [[Tamil cinema and Dravidian politics|relationship between cinema and politics in Tamil Nadu]].{{Sfn|Rangan|2012|pp=164–165}} The following year, he made his [[Bollywood]] debut with ''[[Dil Se..]]'', the third film in his "terrorism trilogy".{{efn|The preceding films are ''Roja'' and ''Bombay''.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oW0-CQAAQBAJ |title=Studying Indian Cinema |publisher=Auteur Publishing |last=Ahmed |first=Omar |location=[[Leighton Buzzard]] |year=2015 |page=186 |isbn=978-0-9932384-9-9 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217105926/https://books.google.com/books?id=oW0-CQAAQBAJ |archivedate=2017-02-17 |df= }}}} A box-office failure in India, the film emerged as a success overseas; it became the first Indian film to be placed among the top 10 at the [[List of highest-grossing films in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom box-office]].{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2022076_2022068_2022065,00.html |title=Dil Se – 1998 |work=Time |date=27 October 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2016 |last=Sattar |first=Miral |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505050645/http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0%2C28804%2C2022076_2022068_2022065%2C00.html |archivedate= 5 May 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} In 2002, Mani Ratnam directed the critically acclaimed drama ''[[Kannathil Muthamittal]]'', which was set against the backdrop of the [[Sri Lankan Civil War]].{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Films-with-Sri-Lankan-connect-run-into-trouble-in-TN/articleshow/40868300.cms |title=Films with Sri Lankan connect run into trouble in TN |work=The Times of India |date=26 August 2014 |accessdate=30 April 2016 |last=Prabhakar |first=Jyothi |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505053410/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Films-with-Sri-Lankan-connect-run-into-trouble-in-TN/articleshow/40868300.cms |archivedate= 5 May 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} The commercial failure was the most successful film at the [[50th National Film Awards]], winning six honours including the award for the [[National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Tamil|Best Feature Film in Tamil]].{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2002/09/04/stories/2002090400060200.htm | title=Switching over to action | work=The Hindu | date=4 September 2002 | accessdate=21 February 2016 | last=Pillai | first=Sreedhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505051433/http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2002/09/04/stories/2002090400060200.htm | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://iffi.nic.in/Dff2011/Frm50NFAAward.aspx?PdfName=50nfa.pdf |title=50th National Film Awards |publisher=Directorate of Film Festivals |accessdate=22 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6hjlYdGU7?url=http://iffi.nic.in/Dff2011/Frm50NFAAward.aspx?PdfName=50nfa.pdf |archivedate=24 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He returned to Bollywood after a six-year hiatus with the political drama ''[[Yuva]]'' (2004); the project was simultaneously filmed in Tamil as ''[[Aaytha Ezhuthu]]'' with a different cast.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2004/may/19esha.htm|title='I am today's woman – very independent, very bindaas'|last=Ashraf|first=Syed Firdaus|publisher=Rediff|date=19 May 2004|accessdate=7 June 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612005830/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2004/may/19esha.htm|archivedate=12 June 2016|deadurl=no}} His next release was the biographical film ''[[Guru (2007 film)|Guru]]'' (2007), a drama inspired by the life of the industrialist [[Dhirubhai Ambani]].{{cite web | first=Kaveree | last=Bamzai | url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/film-review-of-mani-ratnams-guru/1/156632.html | title=Polyester Perfect | work=India Today | date=29 January 2007 | accessdate=18 May 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160524055208/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/film-review-of-mani-ratnams-guru/1/156632.html | archivedate=24 May 2016 | deadurl=no}}{{cite web | first=Syed Firdaus | last=Ashraf | url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2006/nov/06sd1.htm | title=Abhishek goes the Ambani way | publisher=Rediff | date=6 November 2006 | accessdate=18 May 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160524055156/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2006/nov/06sd1.htm | archivedate=24 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} In 2010, Mani Ratnam worked on the Tamil-Hindi bilingual ''[[Raavanan]]''/''[[Raavan]]'', which was based on the Indian epic ''[[Ramayana]]''.{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-sundaymagazine/promises-not-kept/article510094.ece | title=Promises not kept | work=The Hindu | date=11 July 2010 | accessdate=18 May 2016 | last=Srivathsan | first=A. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160524055201/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-sundaymagazine/promises-not-kept/article510094.ece | archivedate=24 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} Three years later, he produced and directed the crime drama ''[[Kadal (2013 film)|Kadal]]'', a critical and box office failure.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/regional-movies/mani-ratnam-s-kadal-in-trouble/story-crGBh1EEjwdmT7n1QV3B5N.html|title=Mani Ratnam's Kadal in trouble|last=Bhaskaran|first=Gautaman|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=13 February 2013|accessdate=7 June 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612005835/http://www.hindustantimes.com/regional-movies/mani-ratnam-s-kadal-in-trouble/story-crGBh1EEjwdmT7n1QV3B5N.html|archivedate=12 June 2016|deadurl=no}} This was followed by ''[[O Kadhal Kanmani]]'' (2015), a romantic drama about a [[Cohabitation in India|cohabiting couple]]. The critically acclaimed film was his first commercial success in the 2010s.{{cite news | url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/mani-ratnams-tamil-film-o-kadhal-kanmani-mints-over-rs-14-crore-in-4-days-of-release/ | title=Mani Ratnam’s Tamil film 'O Kadhal Kanmani' mints over Rs.14 crore in 4 days of release | work=The Indian Express | date=21 April 2015 | accessdate=21 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505052255/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/mani-ratnams-tamil-film-o-kadhal-kanmani-mints-over-rs-14-crore-in-4-days-of-release/ | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}}{{cite news | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-kanchana-2-ok-kanmani-rock-the-box-office-this-week-2079704 | title='Kanchana 2', 'OK Kanmani' rock the box office this week | work=[[Daily News and Analysis]] | date=22 April 2015 | accessdate=19 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505050750/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-kanchana-2-ok-kanmani-rock-the-box-office-this-week-2079704 | archivedate=5 May 2016 | deadurl=no}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |+Key | style="background:#FFFFCC;"| {{dagger|alt=Films that have not yet been released}} | Denotes films that have not yet been released |} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ List of films contributed to by Mani Ratnam ! Championships|2004 Hwacheon]] | Girls' team }} }} '''Nitya Krishinda Maheswari Korwa''' (born 16 December 1988 in [[Blitar]]) is an [[Indonesia]]n badminton player. She is specialized in women's doubles. Her current partner is [[Yulfira Barkah]]. ==Career == Maheswari participated at the 2009 Badminton World Championships, where she reached rank 9 in the women's doubles together with Greysia Polii. In 2011, she won the gold medal at the [[Badminton at the 2011 Southeast Asian Games|Southeast Asian Games]] with [[Anneke Feinya Agustin]].{{cite news|title=(SEA Games) Anneke/Nitya Raih Emas Ganda Putri|url=http://www.badmintonindonesia.org/app/information/newsDetail.aspx?/549|publisher=[[Badminton Association of Indonesia]]|accessdate=1 July 2017|language=Indonesian}} She also won the women's doubles gold medal at the [[Badminton at the 2014 Asian Games|2014 Asian Games]] with Polii.{{cite news|title=Lady shuttlers win gold at Games, after 36 years|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/09/28/lady-shuttlers-win-gold-games-after-36-years.html|publisher=[[The Jakarta Post]]|accessdate=1 July 2017}} She won her first Superseries title paired with [[Greysia Polii]] at 2015 Korea Open.{{cite news|title=Greysia Polii & Nitya Krishinda Maheswari win first Superseries title at Korean Open|url=http://www.yonex.com/sports/badminton/news/badminton/greysia-polii-and-nitya-krishinda-maheswari-win-first-superseries-title-at-korean-open/|publisher=YONEX|accessdate=24 September 2015}} In 2016, she and her partner Greysia Polii were qualified for the [[BWF Super Series Masters Finals]]. However, they withdrew from the tournament due to Maheswari's scheduled knee surgery, and their position was replaced by [[Vivian Hoo]] and [[Woon Khe Wei]].{{cite news|last1=-|first1=admin|title=At Least, Three Badminton Players Withdraw from Dubai SSF 2016|url=http://www.badmintonoise.com/least-three-badminton-players-withdraw-dubai-ssf-2016/534/|website=Badminton Noise|publisher=Badminton Noise|accessdate=22 March 2017}} ==Personal life== Maheswari was born to a [[Papuan people|Papuan]] father and a [[Javanese people|Javanese]] mother. Her father Panus Korwa is a former [[Indonesian national football team|national footballer]] who has notably played for [[Arema Indonesia]]. Her cousin [[Raema Lisa Rumbewas|Lisa Rumbewas]] was a famous lifter and 2 times Olympic silver medalist. Her uncle Levi, Lisa's father, was a bodybuilder.{{cite web|last1=Febriyanti|first1=Imelda|title=Couple: Nitya Buka-bukaan Tentang Dirinya dan Greysia (II)|url=http://www.bola.com/bulutangkis/read/2329677/couple-nitya-buka-bukaan-tentang-dirinya-dan-greysia-ii|website=bola.com|accessdate=9 January 2016|language=Indonesian|date=2 October 2015}} == Achievements == === BWF World Championships === * [[2015 BWF World Championships]] at the [[Istora Senayan]] in [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] {| style='font-size: 90%; text-align: center;' class='wikitable' !colspan=5 style="background:#CC9966;"|[[2015 BWF World Championships – Women's doubles#Finals|2015 BWF World Championships – Women's doubles]] |- ! {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Liao Jingmei]] | align="left" | 15–7, 15–17, 13–15 | style="text-align:left; background:white" | [[File:Med 3.png|Bronze]] '''Bronze''' |} === BWF Superseries (2 titles, 3 runners-up) === The '''BWF Superseries''', launched on December 14, 2006 and implemented in [[2007 in badminton|2007]],{{cite news|title=BWF Launches Super Series|url=http://www.badminton.org.au/index.php?id=22&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=136&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=2&cHash=26fb36d8a5|newspaper=Badminton Australia|date=2006-12-15}} is a series of elite badminton tournaments, sanctioned by [[Badminton World Federation]] (BWF). BWF Superseries has two level such as [[BWF Superseries|Superseries and Superseries Premier]]. A season of Superseries features twelve tournaments around the world, which introduced since 2011,{{cite news|title=Yonex All England Elevated To BWF Premier Super Series Event|url=http://www.ibadmintonstore.com/iBADMINTONstore-News/Yonex-All-England-Elevated-To-BWF-Premier-Super-Se.aspx|accessdate=29 September 2013|newspaper=Badmintonstore.com}} with successful players invited to the Superseries Finals held at the year end. revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox Latter Day Saint biography | name = Otto Fetting | image = PastorOttoFetting1916 cropped.jpg | image_size = 150px | alt = photo of Otto Fetting | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1871|11|20|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Port Huron, Michigan|Port Huron]], [[Michigan]] | death_date = {{Dda|1933|01|30|1871|11|20|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Goodells, Michigan]], [[Michigan]] | spouse = Jennie M. Fetting | children = Roy Fetting | portals = movement <!-- Latter Day Saint Leadership -->
| position_or_quorum1 = Founder of the [[Church of Christ (Fettingite)]] | called_by1 = | start_date1 = April 8, 1930 | end_date1 = January 30, 1933 | end_reason1 =
| position_or_quorum2 = [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|Apostle]] in the [[Church of Christ (Temple Lot)]] | called_by2 = | start_date2 = 1926 | end_date2 = October 1929 | end_reason2 =
| position_or_quorum3 = [[Pastor]] and [[Evangelist (Latter Day Saints)|Evangelist]] in the [[Community of Christ|RLDS Church]] | called_by3 = | start_date3 = 1899 | end_date3 = 1925 | end_reason3 = }}
'''Otto Fetting''' (November 20, 1871 – January 30, 1933) was an American [[realtor]] and [[editor]] from [[Port Huron, Michigan]] who served first as a [[pastor]] and [[Evangelist (Latter Day Saints)|evangelist]] in the [[Community of Christ|Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints]], and then later as an [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostle]] in the [[Church of Christ (Temple Lot)]], commonly referred to as the "Hedrickites". Fetting claimed to have been visited by [[John the Baptist]] thirty or more times between February 4, 1927 and his death on January 30, 1933. Fetting was reportedly given instruction concerning the doctrine and practices of Hedrickites and other factions of [[Christianity]], together with directives to begin construction of a [[Temple (Latter Day Saints)|temple]] on the [[Temple Lot]], including its exact dimensions.
After initially accepting his first eleven revelations, a Hedrickite conference vote in early October 1929 rejected a key portion of Fetting's [http://www.elijahmessage.net/files/message12.html twelfth message], leading him to found the [[Church of Christ (Fettingite)|"Church of Jesus Christ"]] on April 8, 1930. This breakaway faction, later referred to as "Church of Christ", subsequently gave birth to additional rival factions after Fetting's death, which have still further subdivided. These "Fettingite" or "Dravesite" (named after [[W.A. Draves]], a follower of Fetting) factions include: the [[Church of Christ with the Elijah Message|Church of Christ "With the Elijah Message" Established Anew 1929]]; the [[Church of Christ (Restored)]]; the [[Church of Christ (Assured Way)]]; [http://www.elijahmessage.com "The Church of Christ with the Elijah Message, Established in 1929 Anew], [http://www.elijahmessage.net The Church of Christ with the Elijah Message, Inc.] and the [[Church of Christ at Halley's Bluff]].
==Otto Fetting and the Hedrickites== Otto Fetting was born in [[Casco Township, St. Clair County, Michigan|Casco, Michigan]]. Eventually making his home in nearby Port Huron, Michigan, he was baptised into the [[Community of Christ|Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints]] on February 9, 1891, and ordained to its [[Priesthood (Latter Day Saints)|priesthood]] in 1899. In 1925, dismayed by the "[[Supreme Directional Control]]" controversy within the RLDS church, Fetting switched his allegiance to the Temple Lot organization. At the time, this did not require rebaptism or reordination, as each group accepted the priesthood and [[sacraments]] of the other. In the spring of 1926, he was among seven men ordained to be Apostles in the Church of Christ.
==Visitation by John the Baptist== [[Image:Otto Fetting April 6 1929.jpg|left|thumb|350px|Otto Fetting on April 6, 1929 praying at a [[groundbreaking]] ceremony for a proposed [[Temple (Latter Day Saints)|Temple]].]] On February 4, 1927, Otto Fetting claimed that he had been visited by John the Baptist, who delivered a message for him to give to the [[Church of Christ (Temple Lot)|Hedrickite]] organization. This message commanded construction of the long-awaited Temple in [[Independence, Missouri]], first foretold by Latter Day Saint founder [[Joseph Smith]] in 1831. The Temple Lot church had a long history of direction via revelation and angel visits, and thus was originally receptive to these alleged visits of the Biblical prophet, publishing Fetting's messages in their monthly periodical ''Zion's Advocate''. They also began work on the temple with a groundbreaking ceremony held on April 6, 1929. According to Fetting, the Hedrickites were given seven years to complete the structure.
Fetting's "visitor" revealed various architectural details for the building, and specifically directed surveyors to move their markers ten feet to the east of where they had originally been placed. The angel also revealed the location of two of Joseph Smith's original marker stones, which Smith had buried ninety-eight years before to indicate the location for his planned temple. He also indicated that the "Articles of Faith and Practice" of the Temple Lot church were correct, and should not be changed from their original form. On other occasions, the messenger indicated particular men to be ordained within the organization, including to its Quorum of Twelve Apostles.
==The twelfth message== Although the Temple Lot organization had enthusiastically accepted the first eleven of Fetting's messages, this would not hold true for the twelfth. In verse four of this missive, John the Baptist states that all persons coming into the Church of Christ must be rebaptized, as "the Lord has rejected all creeds and factions of men". While this reflects the practice of the majority of Latter Day Saint denominations (including the Temple Lot church itself, today), it did not reflect the policy of the Temple Lot church at the time, which accepted members during this period from the Reorganized church, certain other Latter Day Saint organizations, and Joseph Smith's pre-1844 church on their original baptisms. This message equally declared Fetting to have been given the same "[[Priesthood (Latter Day Saints)#Priesthood keys|keys to the priesthood]]" that were given to [[Joseph Smith]] and [[Oliver Cowdery]] on May 15, 1829.
Controversy over the meaning and application of Fetting's twelfth message became so great that Fetting himself was "silenced" in October 1929 by the Temple Lot organization. Choosing to withdraw rather than continue under such a restriction, Fetting led approximately half of the Church of Christ members (including some of its apostles) to found an organization of his own, which became known as the Church of Christ (Fettingite). Since the main Temple Lot organization retained possession of the Temple Lot and its meetinghouse, Fetting's organization met in members' homes for a considerable period prior to building their own worship facilities.
==Death and testimonial== Fetting would be visited a total of 30 times by his "messenger" prior to his death on January 30, 1933. To the end of his life, Fetting insisted upon the veracity of his heavenly visitor, and the truth of the messages he was given. He authored the following testimony in 1929:
:TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN:
:I make this solemn declaration before God this day, God being my witness, and I expect some day to stand before the judgement bar to answer for this statement.
:The manifestation and words of the visits of the Messenger are true. I have seen him from time to time. I heard his voice, I've seen his face, I saw the light, I felt his hand on my head and the slap on my shoulder. I was enwrapt in that wonderful Heavenly and Divine power, and the words I have given you are not my words, but the words God sent by John the Baptist.
:I want to make this statement, so that everyone may know that this is true; it matters little what will become of me hereafter, but I cannot, nor will not, deny the things I have seen and heard from the Heavenly Messenger as long as I have my right mind, and God gives me life and His grace to endure here on Earth.
:Others may make statements about me, but I want this to be understood that this statement is true. And I shall abide by the advice and instructions given by the Messenger regardless of what men may say.
:Signed Otto Fetting
:Independence, Missouri, October 9, 1929
Four other people claimed to have seen John the Baptist during his final visit to Fetting, and their testimony was notarized.
==Division of the Fettingite organization== Four years after Fetting's death, a young Fettingite [[Elder (Latter Day Saints)|Elder]] named [[W.A. Draves|William A. Draves]] from [[Nucla, Colorado]] claimed that the same messenger who had appeared to Fetting had begun to appear to him, as well. While many of Fetting's followers accepted Draves and his messages, some did not, leading to a split in the Fettingite organization in 1939. Draves' adherents formed the [[Church of Christ with the Elijah Message]], which claims to be the sole legitimate continuance of Fetting's original organization. Draves himself would receive a total of 90 messages prior to his death in 1994, all of which were combined with Fetting's into a book entitled [[The Word of the Lord Brought to Mankind by an Angel]].
The Fettingites who rejected Draves' claims later split into two separate organizations, divided by the decision of the Church of Christ (Fettingite)—the remnant in Independence who rejected William Draves' claims—to introduce the [[Sabbath in seventh-day churches|Saturday Sabbath]] into their organization during the 1950s under Apostle S.T. Bronson. A group of congregations in [[Louisiana]] and [[Mississippi]], under the leadership of A.C. DeWolf, rejected this change and formed the Church of Christ (Restored), which continues to observe Sunday as their day of worship.
Other than disagreeing as to the proper day for worship, the "Bronsonite" and "DeWolf" organizations remain virtually identical in doctrine and practice. Both of them accept Fetting's ministry and messages, but not Draves'. Each rejects the other, and considers itself the sole true continuation of Otto Fetting's church. Draves' organization, on the other hand, rejects both of these groups, accepting their founder's messages ''and'' those of Otto Fetting.
The [[Church of Christ at Halley's Bluff]] has no connection with any of these organizations, though it does accept Fetting's message (but not those of Draves).
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category}} {{portal|Latter Day Saints|Community of Christ}} *[http://www.cesnur.org/2009/slc_addams1.htm The Church of Christ (Temple Lot), and Their Quest to Build a Temple in Zion], by R. Jean Adams. Basic overview of this period of Latter Day Saint history, including Fetting and his messages. *[http://dir.groups.yahoo.com/group/LDSgroups/message/667 John Dawson Blog Entry on the Fettingites]. Contains basic information on the differences between the various Fettingite organizations, acquired from Steven Shields' ''Divergent Paths of the Restoration''. *[http://www.elijahmessage.net/ Church of Christ With the Elijah Message]. Website for William Draves' organization. Offers internal link to all of Fetting and Draves' messages, and the "Articles of Faith and Practice". *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100124085331/http://www.johnthebaptist.info/index_files/Page359.htm Testimonies of Otto Fetting and William A. Draves]. Includes photos of each man. *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_egEAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gS4DAAAAIBAJ&dq=&pg=1494%2C139780 "Temple to be Built by 'Divine Command'] Associated Press report, October 26, 1929, [[Kentucky New Era]] newspaper.
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fetting, Otto}} [[Category:1871 births]] [[Category:1933 deaths]] [[Category:American Latter Day Saint leaders]] [[Category:Angelic visionaries]] [[Category:History of the Latter Day Saint movement]] [[Category:Latter Day Saint movement in Missouri]] [[Category:Latter Day Saint leaders]] [[Category:People from Port Huron, Michigan]] [[Category:Church of Christ (Temple Lot) members]] [[Category:American leaders of the Community of Christ]] [[Category:Religious leaders from Michigan]] [[Category:Religious leaders from Missouri]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{lead too long|date=October 2015}} {{COI|date=September 2015}} {{BLP sources|date=February 2009}} }}
'''Paul Russell Moore''' (born October 1958) is best known as the [[HBOS]] [[whistleblower]] following his dismissal from Halifax Bank of Scotland in 2004. Moore was the bank’s Head of Group Regulatory Risk and was fired from the role by HBOS Group Chief Executive Office James Crosby following his warnings to the Board about HBOS’s risky sales strategies.
In 2009 Moore’s evidence about HBOS was presented to the UK House of Commons Treasury Select Committee and resulted in James Crosby resigning as Deputy Chairman of the Financial Services Authority (now the Financial Conduct Authority). Crosby, who was also an adviser to the then British Prime Minister Gordon Brown, later gave up his knighthood and part of his pension after a Parliamentary report was highly critical of his, HBOS Chairman Lord Dennis Stevenson and HBOS CEO Andy Hornby’s management of the bank. Since his dismissal Moore has been shunned by the financial community and has been unable to find another job in the sector. He has endured depression and alcoholism.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} He has continued to fight for change in the financial system and to bring those responsible for the 2008 crisis to justice.
In 2015 Moore wrote his memoirs in a book called [https://web.archive.org/web/20120805034419/http://www.newwilberforce.co.uk/ Crash Bank Wallop] and has launched [https://web.archive.org/web/20120805034419/http://www.newwilberforce.co.uk/ The New Wilberforce Movement] to free the world from the slavery of greed.
==Early life== Paul Russell Moore was born in Bristol, England on 30 October 1958. He was educated at Ampleforth College in North Yorkshire and studied law at Bristol University.
==Early career== After becoming a barrister he became the in-house lawyer in the product development department of Allied Dunbar in December 1984. He left in December 1988 to join Kleinworth Benson as its in-house lawyer but was only there until April 1989 when he was headhunted by start-up firm Ellastone. In February 1990 he moved to American Express subsidiary Acuma as General Counsel and Head of Compliance and was there until February 1994. In February 1995 Moore joined accountancy firm [[KPMG]] becoming its top-performing Partner.
==HBOS== Moore joined HBOS in July 2002 as Head of Risk in the Insurance and Investment Division. He was appointed to the role of Head of [[Financial risk management|Group Regulatory Risk]] at the end of 2003. He had formal responsibility for the bank's policy and oversight of executive management's compliance with [[Financial Services Authority|FSA]] regulation. It was during 2004 whilst conducting reviews of the bank’s sales culture and selling practices that Moore and his team uncovered mis-selling and other unfair customer sales tactics. However, when Moore reported these findings, as his job demanded, he was fired on 8 November 2004.
Moore's complaints were investigated at the time (before the crisis) by accountancy firm [[KPMG]], who concluded that HBOS had appropriate risk controls in place; this was accepted by the [[Financial Services Authority]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/robertpeston/2009/02/why_crosby_resigned.html |title=Peston's Picks: Why Sir James Crosby resigned |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2015-09-19}}</ref>
In November 2004 Moore was dismissed by [[HBOS]]. He claimed this was because he had told HBOS's board that the bank was taking excessive risks with its aggressive sales culture which was out of balance with its systems and controls. He passed his concerns about HBOS to the [[Financial Services Authority|FSA]], who had it investigated by [[KPMG]], whose conclusion, that HBOS had appropriate risk controls in place, was accepted by the FSA.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>The Choice. (2009). BBC Radio 4. Tuesday 3 November 2009</ref> Following his dismissal the bank replaced him with a retail sales manager.
He sued HBOS for [[unfair dismissal]] on the basis that the reason for his dismissal was actually his warnings of excessive risk, which if followed would have reduced the bank's profits while protecting it from what proved to be the all-too-real risk. The bank settled his claim for over half a million pounds in mid-2005.
In 2008, HBOS was forced into a merger and then bailed out by a multibillion-pound infusion of capital from the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]].
Although Moore had agreed to the [[non-disclosure agreement]] as part of his settlement, he decided to speak out after the crisis because he believed it to be in the [[public interest]] and on 10 February 2009 Moore submitted a memorandum of evidence to the UK's [[Treasury Select Committee]], which was investigating risks taken by UK banks prior to the [[credit crunch]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7882581.stm |title=UK | UK Politics | Text: HBOS whistleblower statement |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-02-10 |accessdate=2015-09-19}}</ref>
==After HBOS== Moore runs a risk consultancy, Moore Carter and Associates,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moorecarter.co.uk/ |title=Risk Governance - Regulation - Ethics - Home Page |publisher=Moorecarter.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-09-19}}</ref> and was the non-executive Chairman of [[Assetz Capital]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.assetzcapital.co.uk/about-us/the-team/ |title=About Us |publisher=Assetz Capital |date= |accessdate=2015-09-19}}</ref> a [[peer-to-peer lending|peer-to-peer lender]] aimed at SMEs and property developers in the UK. Moore is married with three children and currently lives in North Yorkshire.
Moore announced his intention to publish a book about the HBOS whistle blowing and subsequent events called ''"Crash, Bank, Wallop"''.<ref name=RussiaToday>{{cite web|title=Keiser Report: Fraudopian Diet (E601)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zslm3_u_FkY|publisher=Russia Today|accessdate=17 May 2014}}</ref> The book was co-authored by Mike Haworth, edited by [[Guy Mankowski]] and published in November 2015.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Moore, Paul}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:British bankers]] [[Category:British whistleblowers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Ampleforth College]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Peter Raymond Grant | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | field = | alma_mater = {{ublist|[[Cambridge University]]|[[University of British Columbia]]}} | doctoral_advisor = [[Ian McTaggart-Cowan]] | academic_advisors = | workplaces = {{ublist|[[McGill University]]|[[University of Michigan]]|[[Princeton University]]}} | doctoral_students = {{ublist|[[Dolph Schluter]]|[[Peter Boag]]}} | notable_students = | thesis_title = The significance of some insular characteristics in birds | thesis_url = http://hdl.handle.net/2429/41181 | thesis_year = 1964 | website = | known_for = [[Darwin's finches]] | spouse = Rosemary Grant | children = | influences = [[Miklos Udvardy]] | influenced = }} {{Infobox scientist | name = Barbara Rosemary Grant | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | field = | alma_mater = {{ublist|[[University of Edinburgh]]|[[Uppsala University]]}} | doctoral_advisor = [[Staffan Ulfstrand]] | academic_advisors = | workplaces = {{ublist|[[University of British Columbia]]|[[McGill University]]|[[University of Michigan]]|[[Princeton University]]}} | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1985 | website = | known_for = [[Darwin's finches]] | spouse = Peter Grant | children = | influenced = }} '''Peter Raymond Grant,''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|FRS}}, {{postnominals|country=CAN|FRSC}}, and '''Barbara Rosemary Grant,''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|FRS}}, {{postnominals|country=CAN|FRSC}}, are a British couple who are [[Evolutionary biology|evolutionary biologists]] at [[Princeton University]]. Each currently holds the position of [[emeritus]] professor. They are known for their work with [[Darwin's finches]] on [[Daphne Major]], one of the [[Galápagos Islands]]. Since 1973, the Grants have spent six months of every year capturing, tagging, and taking blood samples from finches on the island. They have worked to show that [[natural selection]] can be seen within a single lifetime, or even within a couple of years. [[Charles Darwin]] originally thought that natural selection was a long, drawn out process. The Grants have shown that these changes in populations can happen very quickly.
In 1994, they were awarded the [[Leidy Award]] from the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.<ref name="PANSP">{{cite journal|date=June 2007|title=The Four Awards Bestowed by The Academy of Natural Sciences and Their Recipients|journal=Proceedings of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia|publisher=The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia |volume=156 |issue=1 |pages=403–404 |doi=10.1635/0097-3157(2007)156[403:TFABBT]2.0.CO;2 }}</ref> The Grants were the subject of the book ''[[The Beak of the Finch|The Beak of the Finch: A Story of Evolution in Our Time]]'' by [[Jonathan Weiner]], which won the [[Pulitzer Prize for General Non-Fiction]] in 1995.
In 2003, the Grants were joint recipients of the [[Loye and Alden Miller Research Award]]. They won the 2005 [[Balzan Prize]] for Population Biology.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.balzan.org//premiati.aspx?lang=en&Codice=1117&show=1&from=1117&from1=0|title=Fondazione Balzan|publisher=balzan.org|access-date=24 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052556/http://www.balzan.org//premiati.aspx?lang=en&Codice=1117&show=1&from=1117&from1=0|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Balzan Prize citation states: :Peter and Rosemary Grant are distinguished for their remarkable long-term studies demonstrating evolution in action in Galápagos finches. They have demonstrated how very rapid changes in body and beak size in response to changes in the food supply are driven by natural selection. They have also elucidated the mechanisms by which new species arise and how genetic diversity is maintained in natural populations. The work of the Grants has had a seminal influence in the fields of population biology, evolution, and ecology.<ref name=":1" />
The Grants are both [[Fellow of the Royal Society|Fellows of the Royal Society]], Peter in 1987, and Rosemary in 2007. In 2008 the Grants were among the thirteen recipients of the [[Darwin-Wallace Medal]], which is bestowed every fifty years by the [[Linnean Society of London]]. In 2009 they were recipients of the annual [[Kyoto Prize]] in basic sciences, an international award honouring significant contributions to the scientific, cultural and spiritual betterment of mankind.<ref name=":0" /> In 2017, they received the [[Royal Medal]] in Biology "for their research on the ecology and evolution of Darwin’s finches on the Galapagos, demonstrating that natural selection occurs frequently and that evolution is rapid as a result".<ref>{{cite news|title=Peter and Rosemary Grant receive Royal Medal in Biology|url=https://www.princeton.edu/news/2017/07/18/peter-and-rosemary-grant-receive-royal-medal-biology|accessdate=18 July 2017|work=Princeton University|agency=Office of Communications|date=18 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170719232815/https://www.princeton.edu/news/2017/07/18/peter-and-rosemary-grant-receive-royal-medal-biology|archivedate=19 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Early years== As young children, Rosemary and Peter were both fascinated with the world around them and the animals that inhabited their environments. Their curiosity helped shape them as scientists.<ref name=ahmed1>Ahmed, F. "Profile of Peter R. Grant." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 107.13 (2010): 5703–705. Web. 1 November 2016.</ref>
Barbara Rosemary Grant was born in [[Arnside]], England in 1936. She grew up enjoying the diversity of her surroundings; she collected plant fossils and compared them to living look-alikes. At age 12, she read Darwin's ''[[On the Origin of Species]]''. Despite what teachers told her at school, she was destined to go to university to obtain a degree.<ref name="nair2">Nair, P. "Profile of B. Rosemary Grant." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 108.30 (2011): 12195-2197. Web. 3 November 2016.</ref> She graduated from the [[University of Edinburgh]] with a degree in [[Zoology]] in 1960. For the next year, she studied [[genetics]] under [[Conrad Waddington]] and then devised a dissertation to study isolated populations of fish. This project was put on hold when she accepted a biology teaching job at the [[University of British Columbia]],<ref name="nair2" /> where she met Peter Grant.<ref name="ahmed1" />
Peter Raymond Grant was born in 1936 in London, but relocated to the English countryside to avoid bombings during World War II. He attended school at the Surrey-Hampshire border where he collected insects and studied flowers.<ref name="ahmed1" /> He attended the [[University of Cambridge]], then moved to Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, and began work on a doctoral degree in Zoology at the University of British Columbia. A few days after beginning his research he met Rosemary; they were married a year later.<ref name="ahmed1" />
==Education and career==
===Peter Grant=== * BA (Hons) – Cambridge University- 1960 * PhD – University of British Columbia- 1964 * Post-doctoral fellowship – Yale University- 1964–1965 * Assistant Professor – McGill University- 1965–1968 * Associate Professor – McGill University- 1968–1973 * Full Professor – McGill University- 1973–1977 * Professor – University of Michigan- 1977–1985 * Professor – Princeton University- 1985 * Class of 1877 Professor of Zoology- Princeton University- 1989 * Professor of Zoology Emeritus – Princeton University- 2008 * Visiting Professor – Uppsala and Lund University – 1981, 1985
===Rosemary Grant=== * BSc (Hons), University of Edinburgh, 1960<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.kyotoprize.org/en/laureates/barbara_rosemary_grant/|title=Kyoto Prize, Inamori Foundation|website=Kyoto Prize, Inamori Foundation|language=en|access-date=24 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170716230853/http://www.kyotoprize.org/en/laureates/barbara_rosemary_grant/|archivedate=16 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * PhD (Evolutionary Biology), Uppsala University, 1985<ref name=":0" /> * Research Associate, Yale University, 1964<ref name=":0" /> * Research Associate, McGill University, 1973<ref name=":0" /> * Research Associate, University of Michigan, 1977<ref name=":0" /> * Research Scholar and lecturer, Princeton University, 1985<ref name=":0" /> * Senior Research Scholar with rank of Professor, Princeton University, 1997<ref name=":0" /> * Senior Research Scholar with rank of Professor Emeritus, Princeton University, 2008<ref name=":0" />
==Research==
For his doctoral degree, Peter Grant studied the relationship between ecology and evolution and how they were interrelated. The Grants travelled to the [[Islas Marías|Tres Marias Islands]] off Mexico to conduct field studies of the birds that inhabited the island.<ref name="ahmed1" /> They compared the differences of bill length to body size between populations living on the Islands and the nearby mainland. Of the birds studied, eleven species were not significantly different between the mainland and the islands; four species were significantly less variable on the islands, and one species was significantly more variable.<ref name="grant3">Grant, P. R. "Bill length variability in birds of the Tres Marias Islands, Mexico." Canadian Journal of Zoology 45.5 (1967): 805–815.</ref> On average, the birds on the islands had larger beaks. The Grants attributed these differences to what foods were available, and what was available was dependent on competitors. The bigger beaks indicated a greater range of foods present in the environment.<ref name="ahmed1" />
In 1965, Peter Grant accepted tenure at McGill University in Montreal. He created a method to test the Competition Hypothesis to see if it worked today as it did in the past.<ref name=ahmed1 /> This research was done on grassland voles and woodland mice. The study looked at the competitiveness between populations of rodents and among rodent species.<ref name=grant4>Grant, P. R. Grant, P. R. "Interspecific Competition Among Rodents." Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics, vol. 3, 1972, pp. 79–106. www.jstor.org/stable/2096843.</ref> In his article "Interspecific Competition Among Rodents", he concluded that competitive interaction for space is common among many rodent species, not just the species that have been studied in detail.<ref name=grant4 /> Grant also states that there are many causes for increased competition: reproduction, resources, amount of space, and invasion of other species.<ref name=grant4 />
[[Daphne Major]], in the [[Galápagos Islands]], was a perfect place to perform experiments and study changes within birds. It was isolated and uninhabited; any changes that were to occur to the land and environment would be due to natural forces with no human destruction.<ref name=watch5>"Watching Evolution Happen in Two Lifetimes." Interview by Emily Singer. Quanta Magazine 22 September 2016: n. pag. Print.</ref> The island provided the best environment to study natural selection; seasons of heavy rain switched to seasons of extended drought. With these environmental changes brought changes in the types of foods available to the birds. The Grants would study this for the next few decades of their lives.
In 1973, the Grants headed out on what they thought would be a two-year study on the island of Daphne Major. There they would study evolution and ultimately determine what drives the formation of new species.<ref name=watch5 /> There are thirteen species of [[Darwin's finches|finch]] that live on the island; five of these are tree finch, one warbler finch, one vegetarian finch, and six species of ground finch. These birds provide a great way to study [[adaptive radiation]]. Their beaks are specific to the type of diet they eat, which in turn is reflective of the food available. The finches are easy to catch and provide a good animal to study. The Grants tagged, labelled, measured, and took blood samples of the birds they were studying. The two-year study continued through 2012.<ref name=watch5 />
During the rainy season of 1977 only 24 millimetres of rain fell. Two of the main finch species were hit exceptionally hard and many of them died.<ref name=bach7>Bell, Achenbach, Joel. "The People Who Saw Evolution." Princeton Alumni Weekly 23 April 2014: n. pag. Web. 9 November 2016.</ref> The lack of rain caused major food sources to become scarce, causing the need to find alternative food sources. The smaller, softer seeds ran out, leaving only the larger, tougher seeds. The finch species with smaller beaks struggled to find alternate seeds to eat.<ref name=bach7 /> The following two years suggested that natural selection could happen very rapidly. Because the smaller finch species could not eat the large seeds, they died off. Finches with larger beaks were able to eat the seeds and reproduce. The population in the years following the drought in 1977 had "measurably larger" beaks than had the previous birds.
In 1981, the Grants came across a bird they had never seen before. It was heavier than the other ground finches by more than five grams.<ref name=cressey8>Cressey, Daniel. "Darwin's Finches Tracked to Reveal Evolution in Action." Nature (2009): n. pag. Web. 8 November 2016.</ref> They called this bird Big Bird. It had many different characteristics than those of the native finches: a strange call, extra glossy feathers, it could eat both large and small seeds, and could also eat the nectar, pollen, and seeds of the cacti that grow on the island.<ref name=watch5 /> Big Bird is thought to be a hybrid of the medium-beaked ground finch and the cactus finch.<ref name=cressey8 /> Although hybrids do happen, many of the birds living on the island tend to stick within their own species.<ref name=weiner9>Daniel. Weiner, Jonathan. "In Darwin's Footsteps." New York Times 4 August 2014: n. pag. Web. 9 November 2016.</ref> Big Bird lived for thirteen years, and his descendants have only mated within themselves for the past thirty years, a total of seven generations.<ref name=weiner9 />
Over the course of 1982–1983, [[El Niño]] brought a steady eight months of rain. In a normal rainy season Daphne Major usually gets two months of rain.<ref name=bell6>Bell, G. "Every Inch a Finch: A Commentary on Grant (1993) 'Hybridization of Darwin's Finches on Isla Daphne Major, Galapagos'" Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences 370.1666 (2015): 20140287. Web. 9 November 2016.</ref> The excessive rain brought a turnover in the types of vegetation growing on the island. The seeds shifted from large, hard to crack seeds to many different types of small, softer seeds. This gave birds with smaller beaks an advantage when another drought hit the following year.<ref name=bell6 /> Small-beaked finch could eat all of the small seeds faster than the larger beaked birds could get to them.
In 2003, a drought similar in severity to the 1977 drought occurred on the island. However, in the time between the droughts (beginning in late 1982), the large ground finch ([[Large ground finch|''Geospiza magnirostris'']]) had established a breeding population on the island. This species has diet overlap with the medium ground finch (''[[Medium ground finch|G. fortis]]''[[Medium ground finch|)]], so they are potential competitors. The 2003 drought and resulting decrease in food supply may have increased these species' competition with each other, particularly for the larger seeds in the medium ground finches' diet. Following the drought, the medium ground finch population had a decline in average beak size, in contrast to the increase in size found following the 1977 drought. This was hypothesized to be due to the presence of the large ground finch; the smaller-beaked individuals of the medium ground finch may have been able to survive better due to a lack of competition over large seeds with the large ground finch. This is an example of [[character displacement]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grant|first=Peter R.|last2=Grant|first2=B. Rosemary|date=14 July 2006|title=Evolution of Character Displacement in Darwin's Finches|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/313/5784/224|journal=Science|language=en|volume=313|issue=5784|pages=224–226|doi=10.1126/science.1128374|issn=0036-8075|pmid=16840700|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122034129/http://science.sciencemag.org/content/313/5784/224|archivedate=22 November 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Significant findings== In ''Evolution: Making Sense of Life'', the takeaway from the Grants' 40-year study can be broken down into three major lessons. The first is that natural selection is a variable, constantly changing process. The fact that they studied the island in both times of excessive rain and drought provides a better picture of what happens to populations over time. The next lesson learned is that evolution can actually be a fairly rapid process. It does not take millions of years; these processes can be seen in as little as two years. Lastly, and as the author states, most importantly, selection can change over time. During some years, selection will favour those birds with larger beaks. Other years with substantial amounts of smaller seeds, selection will favour the birds with the smaller beaks.<ref>Zimmer, Carl, and Douglas John Emlen. "Natural Selection: Empirical Studies in the Wild." Evolution: Making Sense of Life. Greenwood Village, CO: Roberts, 2013. 220-23. Print.</ref>
In their 2003 paper, the Grants wrap up their decades-long study by stating that selection oscillates in a direction. For this reason, neither the medium ground finch nor the cactus finch has stayed [[Morphology (biology)|morphologically]] the same over the course of the experiment. The average beak and body size are not the same today for either species as they were when the study first began.<ref>Grant, B. Rosemary, and Peter R. Grant. "What Darwin's Finches Can Teach Us about the Evolutionary Origin and Regulation of Biodiversity." BioScience 53.10 (2003): 965. Web. 10 November 2016.</ref> The Grants also state that these changes in morphology and [[phenotypes]] could not have been predicted at the beginning.<ref name="bio13">"Peter and Rosemary Grant -Bio-bibliography." International Balzan Prize Foundation. Fondazione Internazionale Balzan "Premio", Jan. 2009. Web. 10 November 2016.</ref> They were able to witness the evolution of the finch species as a result of the inconsistent and harsh environment of Daphne Major directly.
==Awards and recognition==
=== Peter Grant === Societies and Academies: * Royal Society of London * Royal Society of Canada * American Philosophical Society * American Academy of Arts and Sciences * American Society of Naturalists (President – 1999) * American Academy of Sciences * Society for the Study of Evolution * Ecological Society of America * American Ornithologist's Union * Linnean Society of London * Society for Behavioral Ecology * Charles Darwin Foundation Honorary Degrees * Honorary Doctorate Uppsala University, Sweden- 1986 * Universidad San Francisco, Quito- 2005 * University of Zurich- 2008 * University of Toronto- 2017 Associate Editor of Scientific Journals * ''Ecology'' - 1968–1970 * ''Evolutionary Theory'' - 1973– * ''Biological Journal of the Linnean Society'' - 1984– * ''Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London'' - 1990–1993 Honorary citizen of Puerto Bacquerizo, I. San Cristobal, Galapagos- 2005–
===Rosemary Grant=== Societies and Academies: * American Academy of Arts and Sciences * Charles Darwin Foundation * American Society of Naturalists * Royal Society of Canada * Royal Society of London Honorary Degrees: * McGill University, 2002 * Universidad San Francisco, Quito, 2005 * University of Zurich, 2008 * University of Toronto, 2017 Honorary citizen of Puerto Bacquerizo, I. San Cristobal, Galapagos- 2005–
Since 2010, she has been honoured annually by the [[Society for the Study of Evolution]] with the Rosemary Grant Graduate Student Research Award competition, which supports "students in the early stages of their PhD programs by enabling them to collect preliminary data... or to enhance the scope of their research beyond current funding limits".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.evolutionsociety.org/content/society-awards-and-prizes/the-rosemary-grant-awards.html|title=Society for the Study of Evolution|publisher=evolutionsociety.org|language=en|access-date=24 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824130108/http://www.evolutionsociety.org/content/society-awards-and-prizes/the-rosemary-grant-awards.html|archivedate=24 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Received jointly=== * 2017 [[Royal Medal]], [[Royal Society]] * 2009 [[Kyoto Prize]], [[Inamori Foundation]] * 2009 [[Darwin-Wallace Medal]], [[Linnean Society of London]] * 2006 Municipality of [[Puerto Rico Ayora]] Science Award * 2005 [[Balzan Prize]] for Population Biology * 2005 Outstanding Scientists Award, [[American Institute of Biological Sciences]] * 2003 [[Grinnell Award]], [[University of California at Berkeley]] * 2003 [[Loye and Alden Miller Award]], [[Cooper Ornithological Society]] * 2002 [[Darwin Medal]], [[Royal Society]] * 1998 [[E.O. Wilson Prize]], [[American Society of Naturalists]] * 1994 [[Leidy Medal]], [[Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia]]
==Publishing== - ''Evolutionary Dynamics of a Natural Population: Large Cactus Finch of the Galapagos'' - Rosemary & Peter Grant - (University of Chicago Press, 1989) {{ISBN|9780226305905}} * Received the Wildlife Publication Award, Wildlife Society- 1991
- ''How and Why Species Multiply: The Radiation of Darwin’s Finches'' - Peter & Rosemary Grant - (Princeton University Press,2008/2011) {{ISBN|9780691149998}}
- ''40 Years of Evolution: Darwin's Finches on Daphne Major Island'' - Peter & Rosemary Grant - (Princeton University Press,2014) {{ISBN|978-0-691-16046-7}}
The Grants were the subject of the book ''[[The Beak of the Finch|The Beak of the Finch: A Story of Evolution in Our Time]]'' by [[Jonathan Weiner]] (Alfred A. Knopf, 1994), {{ISBN|0-679-40003-6}}, which won the [[Pulitzer Prize for General Non-Fiction]] in 1995.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-year/1995 |title=1995 Pulitzer Prize Winners |website=pulitzer.org |publisher=The Pulitzer Prizes — Columbia University |access-date=23 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170615000950/http://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-year/1995 |archivedate=15 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Most recent journal articles=== * "Fission and fusion of Darwin’s finch populations." ''Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society'' B 363: 2821–2829, 2008 * "Pedigrees, assortative mating and speciation in Darwin’s finches." ''Proceedings of the Royal Society'' B 275: 661–668, 2008 * "The calmodulin pathway and the evolution of elongated beak morphology in Darwin’s finches." ''Nature'' 442: 563–567, 2006 (with others) * "Evolution of character displacement in Darwin’s finches." ''Science'' 313: 224–226, 2006 * "Species before speciation is complete." ''Annals of the Missouri Botanical Gardens'' 93: 94–102, 2006 * "The origin and diversification of Galápagos mockingbirds." ''Evolution'' 60: 370–382, 2006 (with others)
==See also== *For other Peter Grants, see [[Peter Grant (disambiguation)|Peter Grant]].
==References== {{reflist|30em}} *Education, accolades, joint awards, and publishing were cited from the International Balzan Prize Foundation bibliography (13)
==External links== *[http://www-dept-edit.princeton.edu/eeb/people/display_person.xml?netid=prgrant Peter Grant's webpage] *[http://www-dept-edit.princeton.edu/eeb/people/display_person.xml?netid=rgrant Rosemary Grant's webpage] *[http://www.princeton.edu/eeb/people/data/p/prgrant/CV.pdf Additional bio information at Princeton website] *[https://royalsociety.org/grants-schemes-awards/awards/royal-medal/ Royal Medal 2017] {{FRS 2007}}
